TRUETOTO.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
TRUETOTO.definition: Female and male total time-related underemployment as a percentage of the labour force

TRUEMAYO.name: Young men time-related underemployment rate, Male
TRUEMAYO.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
TRUEMAYO.definition: Male youth time-related underemployment as a percentage of the labour force

TRUEFEYO.name: Young women time-related underemployment rate, Female
TRUEFEYO.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
TRUEFEYO.definition: Female youth time-related underemployment as a percentage of the labour force

TRUETOYO.name: Youth time-related underemployment rate, Total
TRUETOYO.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
TRUETOYO.definition: Female and male youth total time-related underemployment as a percentage of the labour force

EECYFEDM.name: Youth employment by economic class, developing middle class, Female
EECYFEDM.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYFEDM.definition: The share of developing middle class (between US$4 and US$13, PPP) female youth in total employment

EECYMADM.name: Youth employment by economic class, developing middle class, Male
EECYMADM.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYMADM.definition: The share of developing middle class (between US$4 and US$13, PPP) male youth in total employment

EECYTODM.name: Youth employment by economic class, developing middle class, Total
EECYTODM.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYTODM.definition: The share of developing middle class (between US$4 and US$13, PPP) male and female youth in total employment

EECYFEEP.name: Youth employment by economic class, extremely poor, Female
EECYFEEP.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYFEEP.definition: The share of extremely poor (<US$1.25, PPP) female youths in total employment

EECYMAEP.name: Youth employment by economic class, extremely poor, Male
EECYMAEP.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYMAEP.definition: The share of extremely poor (<US$1.25, PPP) male youths in total employment

EECYTOEP.name: Youth employment by economic class, extremely poor, Total
EECYTOEP.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYTOEP.definition: The share of extremely poor (<US$1.25, PPP) male and female youths in total employment

EECYFEMP.name: Youth employment by economic class, moderately poor, Female
EECYFEMP.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYFEMP.definition: The share of moderately poor (between US$1.25 and US$2, PPP) female youths in total employment

EECYMAMP.name: Youth employment by economic class, moderately poor, Male
EECYMAMP.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYMAMP.definition: The share of moderately poor (between US$1.25 and US$2, PPP) male youths in total employment

EECYTOMP.name: Youth employment by economic class, moderately poor, Total
EECYTOMP.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYTOMP.definition: The share of moderately poor (between US$1.25 and US$2, PPP) male and female youths in total employment

EECYFENP.name: Youth employment by economic class, near poor, Female
EECYFENP.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYFENP.definition: The share of near poor (between US$2 and US$4, PPP) female youth in total employment

EECYMANP.name: Youth employment by economic class, near poor, Male
EECYMANP.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYMANP.definition: The share of near poor (between US$2 and US$4, PPP) male youth in total employment

EECYTONP.name: Youth employment by economic class, near poor, Total
EECYTONP.source: International Labour Organization (ILO) Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM)
EECYTONP.definition: The share of near poor (between US$2 and US$4, PPP) male and female youth in total employment

GEPAYGAP.name: Gender monthly wages gap
GEPAYGAP.source: International Labour Organization (ILO); Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) calculation
GEPAYGAP.definition: Monthly wages of women divided by the monthly wages of men

GWGPOECD.name: Gender wage gap
GWGPOECD.source: OECD, Closing the Gender Gap: Act Now
GWGPOECD.definition: The gender wage gap is unadjusted and calculated as the difference between median earnings of men and women relative to median earnings of men.

GENGAPIE.name: Gender gap in earnings, WDR
GENGAPIE.definition: Ratio of female to male earnings

BLIXEWHF.name: BLI Employees working very long hours, female
BLIXEWHF.definition: This indicator measures the proportion of dependent employed whose usual hours of work per week are 50 hours or more.

BLIXEWHM.name: BLI Employees working very long hours, male
BLIXEWHM.definition: This indicator measures the proportion of dependent employed whose usual hours of work per week are 50 hours or more.

BLIXTLPF.name: BLI Time devoted to leisure and personal care, female
BLIXTLPF.definition: This indicator measures the amount of minutes (or hours) per day that, on average, full-time employed people spend on leisure and on personal care activities.

BLIXTLPM.name: BLI Time devoted to leisure and personal care, male
BLIXTLPM.definition: This indicator measures the amount of minutes (or hours) per day that, on average, full-time employed people spend on leisure and on personal care activities.

MUWFOECD.name: Average minutes of unpaid work per day, female
MUWFOECD.source: OECD, Closing the Gender Gap: Act Now
MUWFOECD.definition: The average minutes spent per day on all of the following activities: routine housework, shopping (grocery, financial services, etc.), care for household members, care for non household members, volunteering, travel related to household activities, and "other" unpaid activities.

MUWMOECD.name: Average minutes of unpaid work per day, male
MUWMOECD.source: OECD, Closing the Gender Gap: Act Now
MUWMOECD.definition: The average minutes spent per day on all of the following activities: routine housework, shopping (grocery, financial services, etc.), care for household members, care for non household members, volunteering, travel related to household activities, and "other" unpaid activities.

FFPOFEAF.name: Percentage of firms with female participation in ownership
FFPOFEAF.definition: Percentage of firms with females among the owners

FFTMFEAF.name: Percentage of firms with female top manager
FFTMFEAF.definition: Percentage of firms with females as the top manager

HRFEDWGP.name: Average hours spent on unpaid domestic work , Female
HRFEDWGP.source: World Bank World DataBank Gender Statistics; Compiled from UNECE
HRFEDWGP.definition: Time spent in domestic work, female refers to average hours per day that women ages 20-74 spent on housework, child and adult care, gardening and pet care, construction and repairs, shopping and services, and household management.

HRMADWGP.name: Average hours spent on unpaid domestic work , Male
HRMADWGP.source: World Bank World DataBank Gender Statistics; Compiled from UNECE
HRMADWGP.definition: Time spent in domestic work, male refers to average hours per day that men ages 20-74 spent on housework, child and adult care, gardening and pet care, construction and repairs, shopping and services, and household management

MMLMLWBL.name: What is the mandatory minimum length of paid maternity leave (in calendar days)?
MMLMLWBL.secondary: Mandatory minimum length of leave (calendar days)
MMLMLWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
MMLMLWBL.definition: What is the mandatory minimum length of paid maternity leave (in calendar days)?

MMLPLWBL.name: What is the mandatory minimum length of paid paternity leave (in calendar days)?
MMLPLWBL.secondary: Mandatory minimum length of leave (calendar days)
MMLPLWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
MMLPLWBL.definition: What is the mandatory minimum length of paid paternity leave (in calendar days)?

PWPMLWBL.name: What percentage of wages are paid during maternity leave?
PWPMLWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
PWPMLWBL.definition: What percentage of wages are paid during maternity leave?

PWPPLWBL.name: What percentage of wages are paid during paternity leave?
PWPPLWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
PWPPLWBL.definition: What percentage of wages are paid during paternity leave?

EGEEPWBL.name: Must employers give employees an equivalent position when they return from maternity leave?
EGEEPWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
EGEEPWBL.definition: Must employers give employees an equivalent position when they return from maternity leave?

CHEMFEIN.name: Children in employment, female (% of female children ages 7-14), female
CHEMFEIN.secondary: study and work, and work only
CHEMFEIN.source: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.
CHEMFEIN.definition: % of female children, ages 7-14, that are employed. Includes those who study and work and those who work only since breakdown by sex not available for individual segments.

CHEMMAIN.name: Children in employment, work only and study and work (ages 7-14), male
CHEMMAIN.secondary: study and work, and work only
CHEMMAIN.source: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.
CHEMMAIN.definition: % of male children, ages 7-14, that are employed. Includes those who study and work and those who work only since breakdown by sex not available for individual segments.

CHEMPSWF.name: Children in employment, study and work, female, (% of female children in employment ages 7-14), female
CHEMPSWF.definition: Children in employment, study, and work, % of female children in ages 7-14

CHEMPSWM.name: Children in employment, study and work, male, (% of male children in employment ages 7-14), male
CHEMPSWM.definition: Children in employment, study, and work, % of male children in ages 7-14

RGDPUSDG.name: GDP growth rate
RGDPUSDG.definition: Percentage change in real GDP, over previous year.

GDPPHEAD.name: GDP/head
GDPPHEAD.definition: Varies across countries: 1) GDP at purchasing power parity (PPP), divided by population and 2) Nominal GDP in US$ translated using purchasing power parity (PPP) exchange rates, divided by population.

NGDPPUSD.name: Nominal GDP (US$ at PPP)
NGDPPUSD.definition: Gross domestic product (GDP) at purchasing power parity (PPP) in US$ (in billions)

RGDPPUSD.name: Real GDP (US$ at PPP, 2005 prices)
RGDPPUSD.definition: Gross domestic product (GDP) at constant market prices, rebased to 2005 constant prices and translated into US$ (in billions) using the LCU:$ PPP exchange rate in 2005.

POPULATN.name: Population
POPULATN.definition: Population, includes mid-year population estimates, end-year population estimates, and in some cases average-year population estimates

POPULATG.name: Population growth rate
POPULATG.definition: Percentage change in mid-year population estimate over previous year.

PURBSLUM.name: % of urban population living in slums
PURBSLUM.definition: The proportion of urban population living in slums is the proportion of urban population living in slum households.

URBANPOP.name: % of population in cities
URBANPOP.definition: Urban population refers to people living in urban areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated using World Bank population estimates and urban ratios from the United Nations World Urbanization Prospects.

RURALPOP.name: % of population rural
RURALPOP.definition: Rural population refers to people living in rural areas as defined by national statistical offices. It is calculated as the % of the total population living in rural areas

GINIINDX.name: GINI Index
GINIINDX.definition: Gini index measures the extent to which the distribution of income or consumption expenditure among individuals or households within an economy deviates from a perfectly equal distribution. A Lorenz curve plots the cumulative percentages of total income received against the cumulative number of recipients, starting with the poorest individual or household. The Gini index measures the area between the Lorenz curve and a hypothetical line of absolute equality, expressed as a percentage of the maximum area under the line. Thus a Gini index of 0 represents perfect equality, while an index of 100 implies perfect inequality.

GNIPHEAD.name: GNI per capita, Atlas method
GNIPHEAD.definition: GNI per capita (formerly GNP per capita) is the gross national income, converted to U.S. dollars using the World Bank Atlas method, divided by the midyear population.

GEDUPGDP.name: Government spending on education as a % of GDP
GEDUPGDP.definition: Public expenditure on education as % of GDP is the total public expenditure (current and capital) on education expressed as a percentage of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in a given year. Public expenditure on education includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration, and transfers/subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).

GOVTEXPH.name: Government spending on health as a % of GDP
GOVTEXPH.definition: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets, external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations), and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds.

AIDRPGNI.name: Net Aid received (% of GNI)
AIDRPGNI.definition: Net official development assistance (ODA) consists of disbursements of loans made on concessional terms (net of repayments of principal) and grants by official agencies of the members of the Development Assistance Committee (DAC), by multilateral institutions, and by non-DAC countries to promote economic development and welfare in countries and territories in the DAC list of ODA recipients. It includes loans with a grant element of at least 25 percent (calculated at a rate of discount of 10 percent).

POVCNTD1.name: Poverty headcount ratio at $1.25 a day (PPP) (% of population)
POVCNTD1.definition: Population below $1.25 a day is the percentage of the population living on less than $1.25 a day at 2005 international prices. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions.

POVCNTD2.name: Poverty headcount ratio at $2 a day (PPP) (% of population)
POVCNTD2.definition: Population below $2 a day is the percentage of the population living on less than $2.00 a day at 2005 international prices. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions.

EDUPGOVT.name: Public spending on education, total (% of government expenditure)
EDUPGOVT.definition: Public expenditure on education as % of total government expenditure is the total public education expenditure (current and capital) expressed as a percentage of total government expenditure for all sectors in a given financial year.

MILEXCOW.name: Military expenditure (% of GDP)
MILEXCOW.source: World Bank; Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Yearbook: Armaments, Disarmament and International Security.
MILEXCOW.definition: Military expenditures data from SIPRI are derived from the NATO definition, which includes all current and capital expenditures on the armed forces, including peacekeeping forces; defense ministries and other government agencies engaged in defense projects; paramilitary forces, if these are judged to be trained and equipped for military operations; and military space activities. Such expenditures include military and civil personnel, including retirement pensions of military personnel and social services for personnel; operation and maintenance; procurement; military research and development; and military aid (in the military expenditures of the donor country). Excluded are civil defense and current expenditures for previous military activities, such as for veterans' benefits, demobilization, conversion, and destruction of weapons. This definition cannot be applied for all countries, however, since that would require much more detailed information than is available about what is included in military budgets and off-budget military expenditure items. (For example, military budgets might or might not cover civil defense, reserves and auxiliary forces, police and paramilitary forces, dual-purpose forces such as military and civilian police, military grants in kind, pensions for military personnel, and social security contributions paid by one part of government to another.)

EMCRFWBL.name: Do employees with minor children have rights to a flexible/part-time schedule?
EMCRFWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
EMCRFWBL.definition: Do employees with minor children have rights to a flexible/part-time schedule?

SEIRPWBL.name: Do male and female spouses have equal inheritance rights to property?
SEIRPWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
SEIRPWBL.definition: For the purpose of this question, it is assumed that the deceased spouse left no children or any other heirs, other than the surviving spouse;This question examines whether both spouses have equal rank and rights when it comes to inheriting assets in the absence of a will;The answer is “Yes” where the law recognizes the same rights to surviving spouses, once his or her spouse is deceased;The answer is “No” where there are gender-based differences on inheritance.

SDEIRWBL.name: Do sons and daughters have equal inheritance rights to property?
SDEIRWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
SDEIRWBL.definition: This question examines whether there are gender-based differences in the rules of intestate succession (that is, in the absence of a will) for property from parents to children;The answer is “Yes” where the law recognizes children as heirs without any restrictions based on gender with regard to property;The answer is “No” where there are gender-based differences between children recognized as heirs, on inheritance for property.

MUEORWBL.name: Do unmarried men and unmarried women have equal ownership rights to property? (Female)
MUEORWBL.secondary: between married men and unmarried women
MUEORWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
MUEORWBL.definition: This question is designed to determine whether there are gender-based differences over property for unmarried men and unmarried women. Ownership rights as used here include the ability to manage, control, administer, access, encumber, receive, dispose of and transfer property;The answer is “Yes” when no specific legal restriction is applied to single women or men, based on gender, with regard to property;The answer is “No” when legal restrictions are applied to single women or men, based on gender, with regard to property.

EORUNWBL.name: Do unmarried men and unmarried women have equal ownership rights to property? (Male)
EORUNWBL.secondary: between unmarried men and unmarried women
EORUNWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
EORUNWBL.definition: This question is designed to determine whether there are gender-based differences over property for unmarried men and unmarried women. Ownership rights as used here include the ability to manage, control, administer, access, encumber, receive, dispose of and transfer property;The answer is “Yes” when no specific legal restriction is applied to single women or men, based on gender, with regard to property;The answer is “No” when legal restrictions are applied to single women or men, based on gender, with regard to property.

CBBOMFEM.name: Seats held by women in central banks, % of total
CBBOMFEM.source: Central Bank Directory; country-specific central bank websites; United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE)
CBBOMFEM.definition: Seats held by women members in Central Banks, expressed as a percentage of all occupied seats

WOMPLRGH.name: Women’s political rights (scored 0 to 3)
WOMPLRGH.definition: Scoring: (0) None of women’s political rights are guaranteed by law. There are laws that completely restrict the participation of women in the political process. (1) Political equality is guaranteed by law. However, there are significant limitations in practice. Women hold less than five percent of seats in the national legislature and in other high-ranking government positions. (2) Political equality is guaranteed by law. Women hold more than five percent but less than thirty percent of seats in the national legislature and/or in other high-ranking government positions. (3) Political equality is guaranteed by law and in practice. Women hold more than thirty percent of seats in the national legislature and/or in other high-ranking government positions.

DOPCPEIU.name: Depth of Political and civic participation
DOPCPEIU.definition: An indicator developed by the Economist Intelligence Unit, composed of the following components: • Female representation in national parliaments, % (average, 1997-2013) • Voter turnout, parliamentary (average, 1995-2013) • Share of ministerial positions (average) • Has the country ever had a -female central bank governor? • Has the country ever had a female head of government? • Was there a woman justice on the Constitutional Court in 2013? • Percentage of female justices on the Constitutional Court (2013) • Year women obtained the right to stand for election • Percentage of females that are somewhat or very interested in politics (average)

WOMJUDIC.name: Women in the judiciary, % of total
WOMJUDIC.source: European Commission; United Nations Economic Commission for Women (UNECE); United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean (UNECLAC)
WOMJUDIC.definition: The UNECE’s definition includes chief justices, judges and magistrates, while UNECLAC’s definition captures women in the highest court or Supreme Court.

WOREPLMC.name: Women's representation on the local/municipal councils, % of total
WOREPLMC.source: European Commission; United Nations Economic Commission for Women (UNECE); United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean (UNECLAC)
WOREPLMC.definition: The definition will vary by source: for example, the UNECE’s definition includes women members of municipal councils and other local area governing bodies, while UNECLAC’s definition captures women elected to city councils. The EIU checked the other UN regional offices’ statistical websites, but they did not have any data for women in the judiciary.

MINPOSFE.name: Women’s share of government ministerial positions
MINPOSFE.source: United Nations Statistics Division via the Inter-Parliamentary Union
MINPOSFE.definition: The proportion of women in ministerial positions out of the total of men and women in ministerial positions. A man or woman at the head of two or more ministries or holding several minsiterial positions is counted only once. The total includes Deputy Prime Ministers and Ministers. Prime Ministers/Heads of Government are also included when they hold ministerial portfolios. Vice-Presidents and heads of governmental or public agencies have not been included.

FEREPNTP.name: Female representation in national parliaments (lower chamber), % of parliament
FEREPNTP.source: United Nations Statistics Division via the Inter-Parliamentary Union; Millennium Development Goals Indicators
FEREPNTP.definition: Number of seats held by women members in single or lower chambers of national parliaments, expressed as a percentage of all occupied seats

EUPVTOUT.name: Voter turnout, EU Parliament
EUPVTOUT.source: International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (IDEA)
EUPVTOUT.definition: Registered voter turnout for EU parliament elections

PARVTOUT.name: Voter turnout, Parliamentary
PARVTOUT.source: International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (IDEA)
PARVTOUT.definition: Registered voter turnout for parliamentary elections

PREVTOUT.name: Voter turnout, Presidential
PREVTOUT.source: International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (IDEA)
PREVTOUT.definition: Registered voter turnout for presidential elections

WOMJUSCC.name: Women justices on the Constitutional Court
WOMJUSCC.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
WOMJUSCC.definition: Number of female justices on the Constitutional Court.

ETPWVLNV.name: Never vote at local elections, % female
ETPWVLNV.definition: Percentage of females that never vote at local elections.

ETPMNTNV.name: Never vote at local elections, % male
ETPMNTNV.definition: Percentage of males that never vote at local elections.

ECWNVVNT.name: Never vote at national elections, % female
ECWNVVNT.definition: Percentage of females that never vote at national elections.

EPMNVNAT.name: Never vote at national elections, % male
EPMNVNAT.definition: Percentage of males that never vote at national elections.

ETPWOAUV.name: Vote (usually or always) at local elections, % female
ETPWOAUV.definition: Percentage of females that usually or always vote at local elections.

ETPMAUVL.name: Vote (usually or always) at local elections, % male
ETPMAUVL.definition: Percentage of males that usually or always vote at local elections.

ETCWAUVN.name: Vote (usually or always) at national elections, % female
ETCWAUVN.definition: Percentage of females that usually or always vote at national elections.

ECPMAUVN.name: Vote (usually or always) at national elections, % male
ECPMAUVN.definition: Percentage of males that usually or always vote at national elections.

IHHEWMVI.name: Percentage of respondents believing that honest elections are either rather important or very important, % female
IHHEWMVI.secondary: believe honest elections are rather or very important
IHHEWMVI.definition: Percentage of females that see it as rather or very important to have honest elections.

IHEFLMRV.name: Percentage of respondents believing that honest elections are either rather important or very important, % male
IHEFLMRV.secondary: believe honest elections are rather or very important
IHEFLMRV.definition: Percentage of males that see it as rather or very important to have honest elections.

INTPOLFV.name: Percentage of respondents who are somewhat or very interested in politics, % female
INTPOLFV.secondary: somewhat or very interested in politics
INTPOLFV.definition: Percentage of females that are somewhat or very interested in politics.

INTPOLMV.name: Percentage of respondents who are somewhat or very interested in politics, % male
INTPOLMV.secondary: somewhat or very interested in politics
INTPOLMV.definition: Percentage of males that are somewhat or very interested in politics.

OTWMBPWW.name: Percentage of respondents who disagree or strongly disagree that men make better political leaders than women do, % female
OTWMBPWW.secondary: disagree or strongly disagree that men make better political leaders than women
OTWMBPWW.definition: Percentage of females who disagree or strongly disagree that men make better political leaders than women.

OTWMBPWM.name: Percentage of respondents who disagree or strongly disagree that men make better political leaders than women do, % male
OTWMBPWM.secondary: disagree or strongly disagree that men make better political leaders than women
OTWMBPWM.definition: Percentage of males who disagree or strongly disagree that men make better political leaders than women.

UNNCTFEW.name: UN peacekeepers, number of contingent troops, female
UNNCTFEW.definition: UN peacekeepers number of female contingent troops

UNNCTMAW.name: UN peacekeepers, number of contingent troops, male
UNNCTMAW.definition: UN peacekeepers number of male contingent troops

UNNMEFEW.name: UN peacekeepers, number of military experts, female
UNNMEFEW.definition: UN peacekeepers number of female military experts

UNNMEMAW.name: UN peacekeepers, number of military experts, male
UNNMEMAW.definition: UN peacekeepers number of male military experts

UNNPCFEW.name: UN peacekeepers, number of police, female
UNNPCFEW.definition: UN Peacekeeping, Number of police office (formed police units and individual police)

UNNPCMAW.name: UN peacekeepers, number of police, male
UNNPCMAW.definition: UN Peacekeeping, Number of police office (formed police units and individual police)

FEMPEACE.name: Women signatories in peace processes, %
FEMPEACE.source: UN Women, Women’s Participation in Peace Negotiations: Connections Between Presence and Influence
FEMPEACE.definition: Share of female signatories of total signatories in specific peace processes the country signed in the year of the data point.

DEMINDEX.name: Democracy Index
DEMINDEX.definition: The Economist Intelligence Unit’s index of democracy, on a 0 to 10 scale, is based on the ratings for 60 indicators grouped in five categories: electoral process and pluralism; civil liberties; the functioning of government; political participation; and political culture. Each category has a rating on a 0 to 10 scale, and the overall index of democracy is the simple average of the five category indexes.

WGICRCOR.name: Control of corruption (Worldwide Governance Indicator)
WGICRCOR.definition: Reflects perceptions of the extent to which public power is exercised for private gain, including both petty and grand forms of corruption, as well as "capture" of the state by elites and private interests. Estimate of governance (ranges from approximately -2.5 (weak) to 2.5 (strong) governance performance)

WGIGOVEF.name: Government effectiveness (Worldwide Governance Indicator)
WGIGOVEF.definition: Reflects perceptions of the quality of public services, the quality of the civil service and the degree of its independence from political pressures, the quality of policy formulation and implementation, and the credibility of the government's commitment to such policies. Estimate of governance (ranges from approximately -2.5 (weak) to 2.5 (strong) governance performance)

WGIPSAVI.name: Political Stability and Absence of Violence/Terrorism (Worldwide Governance Indicator)
WGIPSAVI.definition: Reflects perceptions of the likelihood that the government will be destabilized or overthrown by unconstitutional or violent means, including politically-motivated violence and terrorism. Estimate of governance (ranges from approximately -2.5 (weak) to 2.5 (strong) governance performance)

WGIREGQT.name: Regulatory quality (Worldwide Governance Indicator)
WGIREGQT.definition: Reflects perceptions of the ability of the government to formulate and implement sound policies and regulations that permit and promote private sector development. Estimate of governance (ranges from approximately -2.5 (weak) to 2.5 (strong) governance performance)

WGIROLAW.name: Rule of law (Worldwide Governance Indicator)
WGIROLAW.definition: Reflects perceptions of the extent to which agents have confidence in and abide by the rules of society, and in particular the quality of contract enforcement, property rights, the police, and the courts, as well as the likelihood of crime and violence. Estimate of governance (ranges from approximately -2.5 (weak) to 2.5 (strong) governance performance)

WGIVACCT.name: Voice and accountability (Worldwide Governance Indicator)
WGIVACCT.definition: Reflects perceptions of the extent to which a country's citizens are able to participate in selecting their government, as well as freedom of expression, freedom of association, and a free media. Estimate of governance (ranges from approximately -2.5 (weak) to 2.5 (strong) governance performance)

MWPTPWBL.name: Can married women pursue a trade or profession in the same way as a man?
MWPTPWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
MWPTPWBL.definition: The answer is “Yes” if no permission is needed for a married woman to get a job or practice a trade or profession;The answer is also “Yes” if there is a nondiscrimination or equality provision in the Constitution or Gender Equality Act and no restriction in family or civil law regarding a married woman's ability to work;The answer is also “Yes” if married women and married men have the same rights in marriage and there is no restriction in the family or civil law regarding a married woman's ability to work;The answer is “No” if husbands can prevent their wives from getting or keeping jobs or from pursuing a trade or profession;The answer is also “No” if permission or additional documentation is required for married women to get a job or if a married man can go to court to get his wife's employer to fire her from her job or force her to leave her profession;The answer is also “No” if it is considered a form of disobedience with legal ramifications for a wife to engage in employment contrary to her husband's wishes or the interests of the family.

MWRBMWBL.name: Can married women register a business in the same way as a man?
MWRBMWBL.secondary: register a business in the same way as a man?
MWRBMWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
MWRBMWBL.definition: The answer is “Yes” if full legal capacity is obtained upon the age of majority and there are no restrictions on married women registering a business;The answer is “No” if married women have limited legal capacity to register a business; this would include if they may not legally bind themselves;The answer is also “No” if married women need the permission, signature, or consent of their husbands to register a business;The answer is also “No” if married women are required to provide information pertaining to their husbands during any stage of the incorporation process, but the requirement is not reciprocal.

MWSACWBL.name: Can married women sign a contract?
MWSACWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
MWSACWBL.definition: The answer is “Yes” if full legal capacity is obtained upon the age of majority and there are no restrictions on married women signing legally binding contracts;The answer is “No” if married women have limited legal capacity to enter into contracts or if they need the signature, consent, or permission of their husbands in order to legally bind themselves; this question does not concern restrictions on married women signing contracts specifically related to marital property governed under the default marital property regime; these are covered under the Using property indicator.

NPNDMWBL.name: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women do jobs deemed morally or socially inappropriate in the same way as men
NPNDMWBL.secondary: do jobs deemed morally or socially inappropriate in the same way as men
NPNDMWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
NPNDMWBL.definition: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women do jobs deemed morally or socially inappropriate in the same way as men?

NPNSJWBL.name: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women do the same jobs as men?
NPNSJWBL.secondary: do the same jobs as men?
NPNSJWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
NPNSJWBL.definition: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women do the same jobs as men?

NPNWCWBL.name: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in construction in the same way as men?
NPNWCWBL.secondary: work in construction in the same way as men?
NPNWCWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
NPNWCWBL.definition: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in construction in the same way as men?

NPNWFWBL.name: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in factories in the same way as men?
NPNWFWBL.secondary: work in factories in the same way as men?
NPNWFWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
NPNWFWBL.definition: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in factories in the same way as men?

NPNDAWBL.name: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in jobs deemed arduous in the same way as men?
NPNDAWBL.secondary: work in jobs deemed arduous in the same way as men?
NPNDAWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
NPNDAWBL.definition: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in jobs deemed arduous in the same way as men?

NPNWHWBL.name: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in jobs deemed hazardous in the same way as men?
NPNWHWBL.secondary: work in jobs deemed hazardous in the same way as men?
NPNWHWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
NPNWHWBL.definition: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in jobs deemed hazardous in the same way as men?

NPNMWWBL.name: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in metalworking in the same way as men?
NPNMWWBL.secondary: work in metalworking in the same way as men?
NPNMWWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
NPNMWWBL.definition: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in metalworking in the same way as men?

NPNWMWBL.name: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in mining in the same way as men?
NPNWMWBL.secondary: work in mining in the same way as men?
NPNWMWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
NPNWMWBL.definition: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work in mining in the same way as men?

NPNNHWBL.name: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work the same night hours as men
NPNNHWBL.secondary: work the same night hours as men?
NPNNHWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
NPNNHWBL.definition: Can non-pregnant and non-nursing women work the same night hours as men

UWPTPWBL.name: Can unmarried women pursue a trade or profession in the same way as a man?
UWPTPWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
UWPTPWBL.definition: The answer is “Yes” if no permission is needed for an unmarried woman to get a job or practice a trade or profession;The answer is also “Yes” if there is a nondiscrimination or equality provision in the Constitution or Gender Equality Act and no restriction in family or civil law regarding an unmarried woman's ability to work;The answer is “No” if permission or additional documentation is required, or if a guardian can stop an unmarried woman from working.

UWRBMWBL.name: Can unmarried women register a business in the same way as a man?
UWRBMWBL.secondary: register a business in the same way as a man?
UWRBMWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
UWRBMWBL.definition: The answer is “Yes” if full legal capacity is obtained upon the age of majority and there are no restrictions on unmarried women registering businesses;The answer is “No” if unmarried women have limited legal capacity to register a business; this would include situations in which they may not legally bind themselves with a legal document.

UWSACWBL.name: Can unmarried women sign a contract?
UWSACWBL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
UWSACWBL.definition: The answer is “Yes” if full legal capacity is obtained upon the age of majority and there are no restrictions on unmarried women signing legally binding contracts;The answer is “No” if unmarried women have limited legal capacity to sign a legally binding contract.

COTBOVRE.name: Binary indicator demonstrating whether compulsory to be on the voters register
COTBOVRE.definition: Binary indicator. Countries receive a 'yes' if it is compulsory to be on the voters register.

CBGOVFEM.name: Central bank governor, female
CBGOVFEM.source: Center for Asia-Pacific Women in Politics
CBGOVFEM.definition: Female national bank governors. A country receives a 'yes' for every year that it had a female national bank governor, even if it is the same female for all years. National bank presidents are not included.

NATNQUOT.name: National (Single or lower house of parliament) legislated quotas for women in public office, quota level
NATNQUOT.definition: National (single or lower house of parliament) legislated quotas for women in public office.

SNLLQWPO.name: Sub-national level legislated quotas for women in public office
SNLLQWPO.definition: Sub-national level legislated quotas for women in public office

VPOLPQFW.name: Voluntary political party quotas for women
VPOLPQFW.definition: Voluntary political party quotas for women

YRWOTRSE.name: Year women obtained the right to stand for election
YRWOTRSE.source: UN Women, Progress of the World’s Women 2011
YRWOTRSE.definition: The latest year women obtained the right to stand for election

YRWORTVO.name: Year women obtained the right to vote
YRWORTVO.source: UN Women, Progress of the World’s Women 2011
YRWORTVO.definition: Year women obtained the right to vote

CHJUSWOM.name: Binary indicator demonstrating whether Chief Justice is a woman
CHJUSWOM.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
CHJUSWOM.definition: Binary indicator. Countries receive a 'yes' if the chief justice is a woman.

DDVLIEAB.name: Domestic violence legislation includes emotional abuse, yes/no.
DDVLIEAB.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
DDVLIEAB.definition: The presence of legislation that includes emotional abuse as domestic violence.

HJBWSAWH.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she argues with him (%)
HJBWSAWH.source: Compiled by World Bank from DHS Household Surveys
HJBWSAWH.definition: Survey question; Percent of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she argues with him.

BEATREHQ.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she argues with him (%), highest income quintile
BEATREHQ.definition: Survey question; Percent of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she argues with him, by household wealth index

BEATRELQ.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she argues with him (%), lowest income quintile
BEATRELQ.definition: Survey question; Percent of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she argues with him, by household wealth index

BEATRENE.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she argues with him (%), no education
BEATRENE.definition: Survey question; Percent of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she argues with him, by highest educational level of respondent

BEATREPE.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she argues with him (%), primary education
BEATREPE.definition: Survey question; Percent of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she argues with him, by highest educational level of respondent

BEATRESE.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she argues with him (%), secondary or higher
BEATRESE.definition: Survey question; Percent of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she argues with him, by highest educational level of respondent

HJBWSGOW.name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she goes out without telling him (%)
HJBWSGOW.secondary: when she goes out without telling him
HJBWSGOW.source: Compiled by World Bank from DHS Household Surveys
HJBWSGOW.definition: Survey question; Percent of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she goes out without telling him.

ATTWBYNG.name: Believe wife beating is justified, % women, ages 15-19
ATTWBYNG.source: Population Reference Bureau, The World's Youth 2013
ATTWBYNG.definition: Survey question; Percent of young women ages 15 to 19 who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife under certain circumstances, such as neglecting the children, refusing sexual intercourse, leaving home without telling her husband, arguing with her husband, or burning the food.

ATTWBYWA.name: Believe wife beating is justified, % women, ages 20-24
ATTWBYWA.source: Population Reference Bureau, The World's Youth 2013
ATTWBYWA.definition: Survey question; Percent of young women ages 20 to 24 who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife under certain circumstances, such as neglecting the children, refusing sexual intercourse, leaving home withou telling her husband, arguing with her husband, or burning the food.

EVBPAASF.name: Victims of any form of economic violence by a partner since the age of 15, % women
EVBPAASF.source: FRA gender-based violence against women survey dataset, 2012
EVBPAASF.definition: This includes the partner preventing her from making independent decisions on family finances, or forbidding her to work outside the home.

AFPYVBAF.name: Victims of any form of pyschological violence by a partner since the age of 15, % women
AFPYVBAF.source: FRA gender-based violence against women survey dataset, 2012
AFPYVBAF.definition: This includes behaviour such as belittling or humiliating the respondent in public or private; forbidding her to leave the house or locking her up;making her watch pornographic material against her wishes; scaring or intimidating her on purpose; and threatening her with violence or threatening to hurt someone else the respondent cares about.

SIGIVAWC.name: VAW laws combined SIGI score on domestic violence, sexual assault or rape, and sexual harassment - 2009
SIGIVAWC.source: OECD SIGI Index - The Social Institutions and Gender Index (SIGI) 2009
SIGIVAWC.definition: This variable quantifies information on the existence of laws against (i) domestic violence, (ii) sexual assault or rape, and (iii) sexual harassment as follows: 0 if specific legislation is in place, 0.25 if legislation is in place but of general nature, 0.5 if specific legislation is being planned, drafted or reviewed, and 0.75 if this planned legislation is of general nature; 1 captures the absence of any legislation concerning violence against women. Data is averaged across the three legal categories.

SIGIVAWD.name: VAW laws on domestic violence SIGI score
SIGIVAWD.source: OECD SIGI Index - The Social Institutions and Gender Index (SIGI) 2012
SIGIVAWD.definition: 0: There is specific legislation in place. 0.25: There is specific legislation in place, but there are widespread reported problems with implementation. 0.5: There is general legislation in place, or specific legislation is inadequate (e.g. rape laws do not criminalise marital rape). 0.75: Legislation is being planned, drafted or reviewed or existing legislation is highly inadequate. 1: No legislation.

SIGIVAWR.name: VAW laws on rape SIGI score
SIGIVAWR.source: OECD SIGI Index - The Social Institutions and Gender Index (SIGI) 2012
SIGIVAWR.definition: 0: There is specific legislation in place. 0.25: There is specific legislation in place, but there are widespread reported problems with implementation. 0.5: There is general legislation in place, or specific legislation is inadequate (e.g. rape laws do not criminalise marital rape). 0.75: Legislation is being planned, drafted or reviewed or existing legislation is highly inadequate. 1: No legislation.

SIGIVAWH.name: VAW laws on sexual harassment SIGI score
SIGIVAWH.source: OECD SIGI Index - The Social Institutions and Gender Index (SIGI) 2012
SIGIVAWH.definition: 0: There is specific legislation in place. 0.25: There is specific legislation in place, but there are widespread reported problems with implementation. 0.5: There is general legislation in place, or specific legislation is inadequate (e.g. rape laws do not criminalise marital rape). 0.75: Legislation is being planned, drafted or reviewed or existing legislation is highly inadequate. 1: No legislation.

ADPVFECP.name: Experienced abuse during pregnancy, % women
ADPVFECP.source: UN Women - from DHS, WHO Multi-country study, International Violence Against Women Surveys
ADPVFECP.definition: % of women who experienced abuse during pregnancy

FFSXFECP.name: Forced first sex, % women
FFSXFECP.source: UN Women - from DHS, WHO Multi-country study, International Violence Against Women Surveys
FFSXFECP.definition: % of women who were forced the first time they had sex

IPNPPHCP.name: Intimate partner and/or non-partner violence, physical, % women who experienced in a lifetime
IPNPPHCP.source: UN Women - from DHS, WHO Multi-country study, International Violence Against Women Surveys
IPNPPHCP.definition: Country-specific data on % of women who are victims of intimate partner and/or non-partner physicalviolence in a lifetime.

IPNPPTCP.name: Intimate partner and/or non-partner violence, physical, % women who experienced in the last 12 months
IPNPPTCP.source: UN Women - from DHS, WHO Multi-country study, International Violence Against Women Surveys
IPNPPTCP.definition: Country-specific data on % of women who are victims of intimate partner and/or non-partner physical violence in the last 12 months.

IPNPSVCP.name: Intimate partner and/or non-partner violence, sexual, % women who experienced in a lifetime
IPNPSVCP.source: UN Women - from DHS, WHO Multi-country study, International Violence Against Women Surveys
IPNPSVCP.definition: Country-specific data on % of women who are victims of intimate partner and/or non-partner sexual violence in a lifetime.

IPNPTWCP.name: Intimate partner and/or non-partner violence, sexual, % women who experienced in the last 12 months
IPNPTWCP.source: UN Women - from DHS, WHO Multi-country study, International Violence Against Women Surveys
IPNPTWCP.definition: Country-specific data on % of women who are victims of intimate partner and/or non-partner sexual violence in the last 12 months.

IPVPFECP.name: Intimate partner violence, physical, % women who experienced in a lifetime
IPVPFECP.source: UN Women - from DHS, WHO Multi-country study, International Violence Against Women Surveys
IPVPFECP.definition: Country-specific data on % of women who are victims of intimate partner physical violence in a lifetime.

IPVPTWCP.name: Intimate partner violence, physical, % women who experienced in the last 12 months
IPVPTWCP.source: UN Women - from DHS, WHO Multi-country study, International Violence Against Women Surveys
IPVPTWCP.definition: Country-specific data on % of women who are victims of intimate partner physicalviolence in the last 12 months.

IPVSFECP.name: Intimate partner violence, sexual, % women who experienced in a lifetime
IPVSFECP.source: UN Women - from DHS, WHO Multi-country study, International Violence Against Women Surveys
IPVSFECP.definition: Country-specific data on % of women who are victims of intimate partner sexual violence in a lifetime.

IPVSTWCP.name: Intimate partner violence, sexual, % women who experienced in the last 12 months
IPVSTWCP.source: UN Women - from DHS, WHO Multi-country study, International Violence Against Women Surveys
IPVSTWCP.definition: Country-specific data on % of women who are victims of intimate partner and/or non-partner physical and/or sexual violence in a lifetime.

FHVTINTP.name: Intentional homicide victims killed by intimate partners or family members, % female
FHVTINTP.secondary: Female victims killed by intimate partners or family members
FHVTINTP.source: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC)
FHVTINTP.definition: Intentional homicide victims killed by intimate partners or family members, females, as a percentage of total homicide victims, by country/territory. Intentional homicide is defined as unlawful death purposefully inflicted on a person by another person.

PCTFIHVT.name: Intentional homicide victims, % female
PCTFIHVT.source: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC)
PCTFIHVT.definition: Intentional homicide is defined as unlawful death purposefully inflicted on a person by another person. The % of victims who were female.

RAPEPERS.name: Persons convicted for rape per 100,000
RAPEPERS.source: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC)

RANLPRTL.name: Rape at the national level, number of police-recorded offences per 100,000
RANLPRTL.source: UNODC - United Nations Surveys on Crime Trends and the Operations of Criminal Justice Systems (CTS)
RANLPRTL.definition: “Rape” means sexual intercourse without valid consent. (UN-CTS M3.4) - In the UN-CTS data, the rape rate is calculated per 100,000 population. Therefore the rates for the female population, being the principal victims, are in practice twice as high as those presented.

LACFORES.name: Proportion of land area covered by forest, %
LACFORES.source: Devinfo (via United Nations Statistics Division); Millennium Development Goals Indicators
LACFORES.definition: Forest area is land under natural or planted stands of trees of at least 5 meters in situ, whether productive or not, and excludes tree stands in agricultural production systems (for example, in fruit plantations and agroforestry systems) and trees in urban parks and gardens.

APPMAVGE.name: Air pollution: Average exposure to PM2.5 (Fine particulate matter), total
APPMAVGE.source: Environmental Performance Index, Yale Center for Environmental Law & Policy (YCELP) and the Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN) at Columbia University
APPMAVGE.definition: Population-weighted exposure to PM2.5 in micrograms per cubic meter (µg/m3)

APPMEXCD.name: Air pollution: PM2.5 Excedance, total
APPMEXCD.source: Environmental Performance Index, Yale Center for Environmental Law & Policy (YCELP) and the Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN) at Columbia University
APPMEXCD.definition: This is an average of the percentage of the population exposed to PM2.5 levels at 10 µg/m3, 15 µg/m3, 25 µg/m3, and 35 µg/m3

EPISCORE.name: Environmental Performance Index (2014)
EPISCORE.source: Environmental Performance Index, Yale Center for Environmental Law & Policy (YCELP) and the Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN) at Columbia University
EPISCORE.definition: The Environmental Performance Index (EPI) ranks how well countries perform on high-priority environmental issues in two broad policy areas: protection of human health from environmental harm and protection of ecosystems; overall score out of 100

WJUENVMI.name: Women junior environment ministers
WJUENVMI.definition: Number of women junior environment ministers

WSENVMIN.name: Women senior environment ministers
WSENVMIN.definition: Number of women senior environment ministers

OZDPFEIN.name: Ambient ozone depletion, DALYs, female
OZDPFEIN.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)
OZDPFEIN.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

OZDPMAIN.name: Ambient ozone depletion, DALYs, male
OZDPMAIN.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)
OZDPMAIN.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

APMPFEIN.name: Ambient particulate matter population, DALYs, female
APMPFEIN.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)
APMPFEIN.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

APMPMAIN.name: Ambient particulate matter population, DALYs, male
APMPMAIN.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)
APMPMAIN.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

HHAPFEIN.name: Household air pollution from solid fuels, DALYs, female
HHAPFEIN.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)
HHAPFEIN.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

HHAPMAIN.name: Household air pollution from solid fuels, DALYs, male
HHAPMAIN.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)
HHAPMAIN.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

ENVRFEIN.name: Other environmental risks, DALYs, female
ENVRFEIN.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)
ENVRFEIN.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

ENVRMAIN.name: Other environmental risks, DALYs, male
ENVRMAIN.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)
ENVRMAIN.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

SLPOPURB.name: Slum population in urban areas, %
SLPOPURB.definition: The Proportion of urban population living in slums is the proportion of urban population living in slum households.

WANAOTIM.name: Access to drinking water - improved, other, national
WANAOTIM.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WANAOTIM.definition: Measures the % of given population who have access to improved drinking water from sources other than piped water on premises

WARUOTIM.name: Access to drinking water - improved, other, rural
WARUOTIM.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WARUOTIM.definition: Measures the % of given population who have access to improved drinking water from sources other than piped water on premises

WAUROTIM.name: Access to drinking water - improved, other, urban
WAUROTIM.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WAUROTIM.definition: Measures the % of given population who have access to improved drinking water from sources other than piped water on premises

WANAPIPR.name: Access to drinking water - improved, piped on premises, national
WANAPIPR.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WANAPIPR.definition: Measures the % of given population who have access to improved drinking water from piped water on premises

WARUPIPR.name: Access to drinking water - improved, piped on premises, rural
WARUPIPR.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WARUPIPR.definition: Measures the % of given population who have access to improved drinking water from piped water on premises

WAURPIPR.name: Access to drinking water - improved, piped on premises, urban
WAURPIPR.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WAURPIPR.definition: Measures the % of given population who have access to improved drinking water from piped water on premises

WANATOIM.name: Access to drinking water - improved, total, national
WANATOIM.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WANATOIM.definition: Measures the total % of given population who have access to improved drinking water sources (including from piped water on premises and other sources)

WARUTOIM.name: Access to drinking water - improved, total, rural
WARUTOIM.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WARUTOIM.definition: Measures the total % of given population who have access to improved drinking water sources (including from piped water on premises and other sources)

WAURTOIM.name: Access to drinking water - improved, total, urban
WAURTOIM.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WAURTOIM.definition: Measures the total % of given population who have access to improved drinking water sources (including from piped water on premises and other sources)

WANAOTUN.name: Access to drinking water - unimproved, other, national
WANAOTUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WANAOTUN.definition: Measures the % of given population who still have only access to unimproved drinking water from sources other than surface water

WARUOTUN.name: Access to drinking water - unimproved, other, rural
WARUOTUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WARUOTUN.definition: Measures the % of given population who still have only access to unimproved drinking water from sources other than surface water

WAUROTUN.name: Access to drinking water - unimproved, other, urban
WAUROTUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WAUROTUN.definition: Measures the % of given population who still have only access to unimproved drinking water from sources other than surface water

WANASUWA.name: Access to drinking water - unimproved, surface water, national
WANASUWA.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WANASUWA.definition: Measures the % of given population who still have only access to unimproved drinking water from surface water

WARUSUWA.name: Access to drinking water - unimproved, surface water, rural
WARUSUWA.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WARUSUWA.definition: Measures the % of given population who still have only access to unimproved drinking water from surface water

WAURSUWA.name: Access to drinking water - unimproved, surface water, urban
WAURSUWA.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WAURSUWA.definition: Measures the % of given population who still have only access to unimproved drinking water from surface water

WARUTOUN.name: Access to drinking water - unimproved, total, rural
WARUTOUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WARUTOUN.definition: Measures the total % of given population who still have only access to unimproved drinking water sources (including from surface water and other sources)

WAURTOUN.name: Access to drinking water - unimproved, total, urban
WAURTOUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WAURTOUN.definition: Measures the total % of given population who still have only access to unimproved drinking water sources (including from surface water and other sources)

WANATOUN.name: Access to drinking water - unimproved, total, national
WANATOUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
WANATOUN.definition: Measures the total % of given population who still have only access to unimproved drinking water sources (including from surface water and other sources)

SANATOIM.name: Sanitation - improved, total, national
SANATOIM.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
SANATOIM.definition: Measures the total % of people who have access to Improved sanitation facilities, which include: flush or pour-flush to piped sewer system, septic tank or pit latrine; ventilated improved pit latrine; pit latrine with slab; and composting toilet.

SARUTOIM.name: Sanitation - improved, total, rural
SARUTOIM.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
SARUTOIM.definition: Measures the total % of people who have access to Improved sanitation facilities, which include: flush or pour-flush to piped sewer system, septic tank or pit latrine; ventilated improved pit latrine; pit latrine with slab; and composting toilet.

SAURTOIM.name: Sanitation - improved, total, urban
SAURTOIM.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
SAURTOIM.definition: Measures the total % of people who have access to Improved sanitation facilities, which include: flush or pour-flush to piped sewer system, septic tank or pit latrine; ventilated improved pit latrine; pit latrine with slab; and composting toilet.

SANAOPDE.name: Sanitation - unimproved, open defecation, national
SANAOPDE.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
SANAOPDE.definition: Measures the % of given population who still have only access to unimproved sanitation facilities in the form of open defecation

SARUOPDE.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation

SAUROPDE.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation

SANAOTUN.name: Sanitation - unimproved, other, national
SANAOTUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation

SARUOTUN.name: Sanitation - unimproved, other, rural
SARUOTUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation

SANASHPE.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
SANASHPE.definition: Measures the % of given population who still have only access to unimproved shared sanitation facilities

SARUSHPE.name: Sanitation - unimproved, shared, rural
SARUSHPE.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
SARUSHPE.definition: Measures the % of given population who still have only access to unimproved shared sanitation facilities

SAURSHPE.name: Sanitation - unimproved, shared, urban
SAURSHPE.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
SAURSHPE.definition: Measures the % of given population who still have only access to unimproved shared sanitation facilities

SANATOUN.name: Sanitation - unimproved, total, national
SANATOUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
SANATOUN.definition: Measures the total % of given population who still have only access to unimproved sanitation facilities (including shared facilities, open defecation, and other sources)

SARUTOUN.name: Sanitation - unimproved, total, rural
SARUTOUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
SARUTOUN.definition: Measures the total % of given population who still have only access to unimproved sanitation facilities (including shared facilities, open defecation, and other sources)

SAURTOUN.source: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation
SAURTOUN.definition: Measures the total % of given population who still have only access to unimproved sanitation facilities (including shared facilities, open defecation, and other sources)

AELECPOP.name: Access to electricity, percent of population
AELECPOP.definition: Access to electricity is the percentage of population with access to electricity. Electrification data are collected from industry, national surveys and international sources.

PPSLDFUL.name: Population using solid fuels, percent of population
PPSLDFUL.source: World Health Organisation, Household Energy Database
PPSLDFUL.definition: Percentage of population using solid fuels. Solid fuels include biomass fuels, such as wood, charcoal, crops or other agricultural waste, dung, shrubs and straw, and coal.

GHGETLUC.name: Green house gas emissions total with land use, land-use change and forestry
GHGETLUC.secondary: total with land use, land-use change, and forestry
GHGETLUC.definition: Total green house gas emissions with land use, including land-use change and forestry

DPTYGMTE.name: % of women who have given money to an ecological organisation (past 2 years)
DPTYGMTE.definition: % of female respondents who have given money to an ecological organisation (past 2 years)

DPTYDPEC.name: % of women who have participated in a demonstration for some environmental cause (past 2 years)
DPTYDPEC.definition: % of female respondents who have participated in a demonstration for some environmental cause (past 2 years)

WPENVORG.definition: % of female respondents who have participated in an environmental voluntary organization

WDDLPCFE.name: War and disaster related DALYs, female
WDDLPCFE.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)
WDDLPCFE.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

WDDLPCMA.name: War and disaster related DALYs, male
WDDLPCMA.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)
WDDLPCMA.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

WDRDPCFE.definition: The mean death rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

WRDLPCFE.name: War related DALYs, female
WRDLPCFE.source: Global Burden of Disease by Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (GBD by IHME)

WRDLPCMA.definition: The mean Disability Adjusted Life Years (DALY) rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

WRRDPCMA.definition: The mean death rate per 100,000 attributable to risk factor/mortality cause

NIDPCCOW.name: Number of internally displaced people, total
NIDPCCOW.definition: IDMC’s global IDP figures presented are based on its monitoring of internal displacement caused by conflict, generalised violence, human rights violations and natural hazard-induced disasters. It should be noted that these figures do not include all IDP situations by other causes, such as development projects.

RPBORCOW.name: Refugee population by origin, total
RPBORCOW.source: UNHCR Statistical Online Population Database, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)
RPBORCOW.definition: Refugees are people who are recognized as refugees under the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees or its 1967 Protocol, the 1969 Organization of African Unity Convention Governing the Specific Aspects of Refugee Problems in Africa, people recognized as refugees in accordance with the UNHCR statute, people granted refugee-like humanitarian status, and people provided temporary protection. Asylum seekers--people who have applied for asylum or refugee status and who have not yet received a decision or who are registered as asylum seekers--are excluded. Since 2007 the refugee population category also includes people in a refugee-like situation, most of who were previously included in the Others of concern group. The UNHCR mandate covers all refugees, except some 4.9 million Palestinian refugees residing in areas of operation of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA)

PRSCNCOW.name: Persons of concern, (includes refugees, asylum seekers, returned refugees, IDPs, returned IDPs, stateless persons)
PRSCNCOW.source: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)
PRSCNCOW.definition: Persons of Concern is a term used to describe all people whose protection and assistance needs are of interest to UNHCR, including: refugees, asylum seekers, returned refugees, internally displaced people (IDP), returned IDPs, and stateless persons.

NPOFPCOW.name: Number of police officers per 100,000, total
NPOFPCOW.source: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC)
NPOFPCOW.definition: Personnel in public agencies as of 31 December whose principal functions are the prevention, detection and investigation of crime and the apprehension of alleged offenders. Data concerning support staff (secretaries, clerts, etc.) should be excluded.

NMLPLCOW.name: Number of military personnel, total
NMLPLCOW.source: World Bank; International Institute for Strategic Studies, The Military Balance
NMLPLCOW.definition: Armed forces personnel are active duty military personnel, including paramilitary forces if their training, organization, equipment, and control suggest they may be used to support or replace regular military forces.

GPITOASC.name: Global Peace Index, Overall Score
GPITOASC.definition: The overall Global Peace Index score measures the level of peace in a country. It is a weighted score of internal and external peace. Scores are from 1 to 5, with 1 being the most peaceful and 5 being the least peaceful.

TRFKNGRP.name: Trafficking in persons (TIP) country classification
TRFKNGRP.definition: TIER 1: Countries whose governments fully comply with the Trafficking Victims Protection Act’s (TVPA) minimum standards. TIER 2: Countries whose governments do not fully comply with the TVPA’s minimum standards, but are making significant efforts to bring themselves into compliance with those standards. TIER 2 WATCHLIST: Countries whose governments do not fully comply with the TVPA’s minimum standards, but are making significant efforts to bring themselves into compliance with those standards AND: a) The absolute number of victims of severe forms of trafficking is very significant or is significantly increasing; b) There is a failure to provide evidence of increasing efforts to combat severe forms of trafficking in persons from the previous year; or c) The determination that a country is making significant efforts to bring itself into compliance with minimum standards was based on commitments by the country to take additional future steps over the next year. TIER 3: Countries whose governments do not fully comply with the minimum standards and are not making significant efforts to do so.

ITLTADVL.name: Legislation exists that specifically addresses domestic violence, yes/no.
ITLTADVL.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
ITLTADVL.definition: There is legislation that specifically addresses domestic violence.

ISTLGASH.name: Legislation exists that specifically addresses sexual harassment, yes/no.
ISTLGASH.source: World Bank, Women Business and the Law
ISTLGASH.definition: There is legislation that specifically addresses sexual harassment.

FEMNSENV.name: Female minister of environment

FEMNSENV.definition: Yes/no if the current minister of environment is female

FROPIRSF.name: Freedom of the Press (FOTP) score by Freedom House
FROPIRSF.definition: The index assesses the degree of print, broadcast, and internet freedom in every country in the world, analyzing the events of each calendar year. It provides numerical rankings and scores (as well as categorisations of each country's media as "Free," "Partly Free," or "Not Free.")

ENFCONSF.name: Freedom of the Press (FOTP) status by Freedom House
ENFCONSF.definition: The index assesses the degree of print, broadcast, and internet freedom in every country in the world, analyzing the events of each calendar year. It provides numerical rankings and scores (as well as categorisations of each country's media as "Free," "Partly Free," or "Not Free.")
